Fig. 1 Three approaches for synthesis of broad MWD PE. Fig. 2 Molecular structures of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes with thermal ellipsoids of 50 % probability. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Fig. 3 Topographic steric maps of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes. Fig. 4 Free energies ΔG of syn and anti diastereomers of cobalt complexes. Fig. 5 The π-π interaction regions in cobalt complexes through the space function interaction region indicator. Fig. 6 UV–Vis absorptions of cobalt complexes in CH2Cl2. Fig. 7 Gibbs free energies (ΔG in kcal/mol) of cobalt intermediates for ethylene coordination and insertion. Fig. 8 GPC curves of PEs produced by Co-OMe at different temperatures (entries 1–6 in Table 2). Fig. 9 Peak fitting analysis of GPC curves of PEs produced by Co-OMe at −10 (left) and 10 °C (right), peak molecular weight (kg/mol). Fig. 10 GPC curves of the polyethylenes produced by the Co-OMe at different Al/Co ratios (entries 1–4 in Table 3) (A) and 1H NMR spectrum of soluble fraction of PE (entry 2 in Table 2) (B). Scheme 1 Synthetic routine of the bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes. Scheme 2 Proposed formation mechanism of multi-modal distribution PE. Graphical abstract As the largest amount of worldwide produced polymeric materials, the broad applicability requires polyethylene (PE) to possess good processability and mechanical properties through tailored molecular weight (MW) and molecular weight distribution (MWD). Direct synthesis of broad MWD PE with ultra-high molecular weight component is highly desirable and challenging. In this paper, a series of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes with substituted 8-(p-R-phenyl)naphthylamine (R = OMe, Me, H, CF3) were designed and synthesized for ethylene polymerization. The intramolecular π-π interactions between the capping aryl groups and the pyridyl ring are clearly observed in bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes, which are a crucial driving force for highly active ethylene polymerization. The existence of syn and anti diastereomers of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes is also proved by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The ultra-broad MWD PE (MWD >100) with M w from hundreds to ten million is produced, which is a cooperative result of syn and anti diastereomers of cobalt catalysts and two chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to the monomer and chain transfer to aluminum. Keywords Bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt Diastereomer π–π Interaction Broad distribution polyethylene Chain transfer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyolefins, among them polyethylene (PE), represent the largest amount of worldwide produced polymeric materials with annual production of >200 million tons [1–3]. The broad applicability requires PE to possess goodmanufacturing, processing, and mechanical properties, which are closely related to its molecular weight (MW), molecular weight distribution (MWD), and branching topology. For example, PE with broad MWD exhibits slow crack growth, good impact resistance, and improved processability [4,5]. Among them, low MW components often increase shear rates and improve processability while high MW components can lend excellent mechanical properties including increased tensile strength and toughness [6]. Especially ultra-high molecular weight PE (UHMWPE), consisting of chains with weight average molecular weight (M w) higher than 106 g/mol, there is an urge to achieve PE processability and mechanical properties through tailored MW and MWD [7–9]. Blending of PEs with different MWs is a common approach to tailoring MW and MWD, but has to suffer from poor compatibility and inhomogeneous blends [10–13]. Therefore, the direct synthesis of broad MWD PE by transition metal-catalyzed ethylene polymerization has attracted long-standing interest. Currently, three approaches have been employed in synthesis of broad MWD PE. With the help of multiple-site catalysts (e.g. Ziegler-Natta catalysts) or mixtures of several single-site catalysts, tailor-made broad MWD PE can be prepared (pathway 1 in Fig. 1 ) [14–17]. Besides, isomers and syn/anti diastereomers of single-site catalysts also afford broad MWD PE (pathway 2 in Fig. 1). Especially α-diimine Ni/Pd catalysts with asymmetric ortho-aryl substituents, where the existence of syn/anti diastereomers often affords bimodal distribution PE [18–21]. Additionally, broad MWD PE is produced through different chain transfer modes in single-site metal catalyzed ethylene polymerization (pathway 3 in Fig. 1). A representative sample is bis(imino)pyridyl iron/cobalt catalyst, which produces bimodal distribution PE because of two chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to monomer and chain transfer to aluminum [22–24]. Despite these contributions, the synthesis of ultra-broad MWD PE with UHMWPE component is highly challenging. As a kind of late transition metal catalysts, bis(imino)pyridyl iron/cobalt catalysts have received intensive attention because they afford fully linear PE with high catalytic activity [22–28]. For bis(imino)pyridyl Fe/Co catalysts, the demand for bulk ortho-aryl substituents is a crucial factor in achieving high MW, but has to suffer from reducing activity because the bulky hindrance often hinders the coordination and insertion of ethylene monomer [29–34]. Therefore, synthesis of UHMWPE using bis(imino)pyridyl Fe/Co catalysts has rarely been reported, especially the less active cobalt-based catalysts [35–37]. Beyond electronic and steric tuning, we have previously developed a series of “sandwich” bis(imino)pyridyl iron catalysts derived from 8-arylnaphthylamines and found that weak noncovalent π-π interactions are a crucial driving force for ethylene polymerization [38,39]. Inspired by unprecedented effects of π-π interactions in iron catalysts, a series of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt analogues with substituted 8-(p-R-phenyl)naphthylamine (R = OMe, Me, H, CF3) were herein developed. The π-π interactions were clearly observed in bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes and played a crucial role in ethylene polymerization. Furthermore, ultra-broad MWD PE (MWD >100) with M w from hundreds to ten million was produced, which was a cooperative result of syn/anti diastereomers of cobalt catalysts and different chain transfer modes. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of cobalt complexes Four bis(imino)pyridyl ligands (L-OMe, L-Me, L-H, L-CF3 ) were synthesized by a condensation reaction of 2,6-diacetyl pyridine with substituted 8-(p-R-phenyl)naphthylamine (R = OMe, Me, H, CF3) in high yield [38]. New cobalt complexes (Co-OMe, Co-Me, Co-H, Co-CF3 ) were synthesized by the complexation reaction of the corresponding ligands with CoCl2 in THF solvent (Scheme 1 ). Single crystals of four cobalt complexes suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained through the slow diffusion of cobalt complex solution in CH2Cl2/hexane mixture solvent. According to previous crystal data of late transition metal complexes derived from 8-arylnaphthylamines [38,40,41], four cobalt complexes with capping aryl substituents were expected to have a “sandwich” structure. Indeed, four anti diastereomers of cobalt complexes show a “sandwich” structure (Fig. 2 ). The capping aryl substituents are positioned above and below the chelate ring. The capping aryl substituents provide bulky steric hindrance around the cobalt center, which is calculated by the space-filling capabilities of the metal center. The buried volumes (%VBur) of four anti diastereomers Co-OMe, Co-Me, Co-H, and Co-CF 3 (Fig. 3 ) are 59.1, 59.4, 58.1, and 58.0, respectively, which are bigger than that of classic bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complex with 2,6-diisopropylanilines (56.6) [42], indicating bulky steric effect of the capping aryl substituents. Besides, the substituent R on the capping aryl does not show the steric effects based on nearly the same buried volumes. In principle, there are syn and anti diastereomers of transition metal complexes derived from 2,6-asymmetric anilines because the two naphthyl rings are oriented on the same or contrary side of the chelate ring. The “sandwich” α-diimine Ni/Pd complexes with the capping aryl substituents usually exist as the anti form in the solid state because of steric repulsion between two capping aryl substituents [18,40,41]. To our surprise, another single crystal of syn diastereomer of Co-Me was also obtained. For syn Co-Me, the capping aryl substituents are positioned in the same spatial orientation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first crystal structure of syn diastereomer of late transition metal complexes derived from bulky 8-arylnaphthylamines [43]. The syn diastereomer of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complex (syn Co-Me) without a “sandwich” structure is first found, while syn diastereomer of α-diimine Ni/Pd complexes has never been observed because bis(imino)pyridyl complexes have more open space than α-diimine Ni/Pd complexes based on long N–N distances of two imine nitrogen atoms (N–N distance: bis(imino)pyridyl (4.36 Å) > α-diimine (2.45 Å)) [24,40]. In fact, another capping aryl substituent of syn Co-Me is deviated from the cobalt center because of the steric repulsion between two capping aryl substituents (see Fig. 2). The calculated buried volumes (%VBur) of syn and anti diastereomers of Co-Me are 59.4 and 58.5, indicating that the anti diastereomer is bulkier than syn diastereomer. Although single crystals of syn diastereomers of Co-OMe and Co-CF3 were not obtained, syn Co-OMe and syn Co-CF3 were also expected to exist based on nearly same calculated buried volumes (Fig. 3). DFT calculations were further performed to prove the presence of syn diastereomers (see computational details in the SI). As shown in Fig. 4 , three anti diastereomer have a lower free energy ΔG than corresponding syn diastereomers (ΔG = −2.1, −4.2, −4.5 kcal/mol). The small ΔG values strongly indicate that syn Co-OMe and syn Co-CF3 are also present. Therefore, it is safely concluded that syn and anti diastereomers of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes exist together, which is expected to impact ethylene polymerization [18–21]. Like our previously reported “sandwich” bis(imino)pyridyl iron complexes,38 four anti diastereomers of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes also exhibit intramolecular π-π interactions between the capping aryl substituent and the pyridyl ring with offset face-to-face pattern. Crystal parameters in Table 1 clearly show that dihedral angles between the capping aryl groups and the pyridyl ring are below 15° and the centroid–centroid distances of the two aromatic rings are within 3.4 Å, strongly indicating the existence of intramolecular π-π interactions [44]. It is noteworthy that only one capping aryl substituent is nearly parallel to the pyridyl ring and the other capping aryl substituent is deviated in syn Co-Me (Fig. 2). Resultantly, anti Co-Me has stronger intramolecular π-π interactions than syn Co-Me. The π-π interaction regions in cobalt complexes were directly and graphically revealed in Fig. 5 through the space function interaction region indicator (IRI) [45]. The intramolecular π-π interaction energies ΔE were also computed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations using the M06-L functional and def2-SVP basis sets (Table 1) [46]. The calculated ΔE values clearly support that the introductions of CF3 and OMe groups on the capping aryl substituent reinforce the intramolecular π-π interactions [38]. In addition to X-ray single crystal structures and DFT calculations of cobalt complexes, the presence of the intramolecular π-π interactions of cobalt complexes in solution is also spectroscopically proven [44,47]. To clearly clarify the effect of the capping aryl groups, a bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complex Co-0 without capping aryl groups (see Scheme 1) was also synthesized and used as a comparison (Scheme S1 in SI). As shown in Fig. 6 , the UV–Vis spectra of cobalt complexes in CH2Cl2 solvent reveal two absorption peaks at 233 and ∼300 nm. Compared to reference complex Co-0 without the capping aryl substituents, four cobalt complexes with capping aryl substituents exhibit a bathochromic-shifted absorption at ∼300 nm, supporting the existence of intramolecular π-π interactions in solution of cobalt complexes. The order of the bathochromic-shift wavenumber is Co-CF 3 > Co-OMe > Co-Me = Co-H, which is basically consistent with the π-π interaction energy ΔE. 2.2 Ethylene polymerization For late transition metal catalysts, a key feature for producing high-molecular-weight polyethylene lies in suppression of rapid chain transfer by the steric bulk of the o-aryl substituents [48–53]. However, bulky N-aryl substituents of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt catalysts usually cause a significant reduction in polymerization activity because of their inhibition of the coordination of ethylene monomer [30,54–56]. For instance, bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt catalysts with bulky 2,6-dibenzhydrylaniline moieties reported by Sun show extremely low activity to afford traces of polymer for ethylene polymerization [32]. Herein, ethylene polymerizations were screened using four bulky bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes activated by 1000 equiv. MAO at different reaction temperatures. As shown in Table 2 , Co-Me and Co-H are inactive for ethylene polymerization at −20 to 30 °C. Strikingly, Co-CF3 shows moderate activity (0.27 × 106 g PE/ (mol Co·h)) while Co-OMe exhibits high activity up to 3.25 × 106 g PE/ (mol Co·h)) although four cobalt catalysts have nearly the same steric hindrance based on the calculated buried volumes. Clearly, this huge difference in ethylene polymerization activity among four cobalt catalysts is not ascribed to steric effect. Besides, the electronic effect of para-substituent R on the phenyl can be reflected by Hammett constants (σ) [57–62]. The electron-donating ability of substituent R decreases in the order of OMe (σ = −0.268) > Me (σ = −0.170) > H (σ = −0.170) > CF3 (σ = +0.540) based on σ values of R groups. Therefore, the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst is not a result of the electronic effect of substituent R. Based on the intensity of intermolecular π-π interactions (CF3 > OMe > Me = H) of four cobalt catalysts determined by UV–Vis analysis and theoretical calculation, the π-π interactions should be a crucial driving force for ethylene polymerization, which has been proved in our previously reported iron analogues [38,39]. Unlike iron based catalysts, cobalt catalyst Co-OMe is more active than Co-CF3 , which is ascribed to the effect of metal center [24,63]. To better understand the effect of the π-π interactions on ethylene polymerization, the theoretical DFT calculations for cobalt catalysts were performed. The optimized methyl cobalt intermediate with a vacancy (IM-1) is regarded as the initial cobalt species. The coordination of ethylene monomer to the cobalt species (IM-1) needs to overcome certain energy barrier (ΔGCoord.), which affords cobalt intermediate (IM-2) with the bound ethylene. As shown in Fig. 7 , Co-Me and Co-H have very high energy barriers (ΔGCoord.: 29.2 and 28.7 kcal/mol) while Co-OMe and Co-CF3 have low energy barriers (ΔGCoord.: 13.4 and 14.5 kcal/mol), indicating that ethylene coordination can occur for Co-OMe and Co-CF3 but cannot take place for Co-Me and Co-H. The ethylene insertion into IM-2 produces IM-4 with the bound ethylene. DFT calculation results clearly show that ethylene insertions are thermodynamically favorable with −15.3 kcal/mol for Co-OMe and −11.9 kcal/mol for Co-CF3 . Two ethylene coordination procedures (IM-1 to IM-2 and IM-3 to IM-4) are shown with contrary energy barrier for Co-OMe and Co-CF3 , which is a result of steric repulsion. It is believable that the methyl cobalt intermediate (IM-1) has more crowded space than IM-3 because large-size propyl can make capping aryl groups tilt away from the cobalt center. The calculation results clearly shows that the nearest distances of Co–CPh of IM-1 (2.85, 2.86 Å for Co-OMe and 2.84, 2.85 Å for Co-CF3 ) are shorter than those of IM-3 (2.93, 3.85 Å for Co-OMe and 2.83, 3.98 Å for Co-CF3 ) (Table S3). Therefore, ethylene coordination to bulky IM-1 need to overcome high energy barrier. Considering fast activation of cobalt complexes by MAO cocatalyst [65,66], it is safely concluded that the ethylene coordination to the cobalt center is a crucial step for bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt-catalyzed ethylene polymerization. Besides, the polymerization activities of Co-OMe and Co-CF3 decreased significantly with increasing temperature from −10 °C to 30 °C, and no activity was observed above 30 °C. Firstly, rapid chain transfer is excluded because no liquid α-olefins are produced. Secondly, catalyst deactivation is also excluded because cobalt complexes are very stable at room temperature (30 °C). It is speculated that the decreasing polymerization activity with increasing temperatures is probably attributed to the effect of π-π interactions. The π-π interaction are weakened at elevated temperatures [64], which making the naphthyl rings shift back toward the metal center. Resultantly, cobalt catalysts with more crowded space around the metal center are inactive. 2.3 Ultra-broad molecular weight distribution polyethylene It is noteworthy that ultra-broad molecular weight distribution polyethylenes are produced by catalyst Co-OMe and Co-CF3 at −10 to 30 °C. Especially, catalyst Co-OMe, MWDs of PEs are high up to >100. GPC curves of PEs in Fig. 8 clearly show that multi-modal distribution except the PE sample produced at −20 °C. Unlike narrow MWD PEs produced by previously reported bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt [35], the PEs produced by catalyst Co-OMe at −10 to 30 °C contain very low-molecular-weight PE wax component with M w of hundreds (log M w ≈ 2) and UHMWPE component with M w up to ten million (log M w > 7). To the best of our knowledge, this is an extremely rare report on direct synthesis of ultra-broad MWD polyethylene containing UHMWPE component [67–70]. Although ultra-broad MWD polyethylenes contain multiple components, their DSC curves do not show multiple melting peaks (Figs. S1–S3). DSC curves of polyethylenes are smooth and have a broad melting endotherm because of successive components. To deeply understand the formation mechanism of ultra-broad MWD polyethylene, two representative GPC curves of PEs produced by Co-OMe at −10 and 10 °C were further executed peak fitting analysis. As shown in Fig. 9 , GPC curves can be divided into four normal distribution GPC curves, indicating a multi-modal distribution. Previously, Gibson and Brookhart have found that the PEs produced by the classic bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt catalyst have a bimodal distribution [22–24]. Gibson also identified that the bimodal distribution of the resultant PE originates from two different chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to monomer and chain transfer to aluminum [24]. For cobalt-based catalysts, the low molecular weight portion is subject to β-H transfer to monomer while the high molecular weight fraction is subject to chain transfer to aluminum. Recently, Dai also reported that the effect of metal center on the chain transfer mode in bis(imino)pyridyl iron and cobalt-catalyzed ethylene polymerization, and the low molecular weight portion is subject to β-H transfer to ethylene for cobalt-based catalysts [63]. To further distinguish chain transfer pathway for low molecular weight fraction, the highly active catalyst Co-OMe was selected to further study its chain transfer pathways by the effects of Al/Co ratios on ethylene polymerization. As shown in Table 3 , polymerization activity first increases and then decreases with increasing Al/Co ratios from 1000 to 2000, and reaches the highest activity at Al/Co = 1000. However, PE molecular weight decreases consistently and low MW portion increases in GPC curves with increasing Al/Co ratio (Table 3), indicating the existence of chain transfer to aluminum. Besides, we also note that the start points of GPC curves are the same (Fig. 10 A), indicating the lowest molecular weight of PE is not impacted by Al/Co ratio. This result strongly indicates that the low molecular weight is not a result of chain transfer to aluminum. The resultant PE product was further extracted in chloroform, and the soluble fraction was low molecular weight PE. 1H NMR analysis (Fig. 10B) shows that most of the soluble fraction is unsaturated and fully linear polyethylene with a vinyl end based on the characteristic vinyl protons at 5.74 and 4.90 ppm. Therefore, it is safely concluded that the low molecular weight portion is subject to β-H transfer to ethylene monomer while the high molecular weight fraction is subject to chain transfer to aluminum in Co-OMe catalyzed ethylene polymerization. Besides, single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and DFT calculations of cobalt complex proves the existence of anti and syn diastereomers and anti diastereomer is bulkier than syn diastereomer. In α-diimne nickel and palladium catalysts with asymmetric ortho-aryl substituents, anti and syn diastereomers have been proved to produce bimodal distribution PE [18–21]. The anti diastereomer affords high MW portion, and the syn diastereomer produces low MW portion because bulky anti diastereomers can block the axial coordination sites more efficiently. Herein, bimodal distribution PE is also expected to be produced in our cobalt catalytic systems. Generally, GPC curves with four fitting curves (Fig. 8) should be a result of two chain transfer pathways and two anti and syn diastereomers. Based on chain transfer pathways and steric hindrances of anti and syn diastereomers, we make a reasonable assignment for four fitting curves (Scheme 2 ). The anti diastereomer produced the highest molecular weight through chain transfer to aluminum, while syn diastereomer produced the lowest molecular weight through β-H transfer to ethylene. Our assignment is also supported by the proportion of four fractions. As mentioned above, anti diastereomer is more stable than syn diastereomer and has higher proportion in cobalt complex. Correspondingly, anti diastereomer also affords higher proportion fraction than syn diastereomer (fractions 4 and 2 > fractions 3 and 1). 3 Conclusions In summary, we have synthesized and characterized a series of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes with substituted 8-(p-R-phenyl)naphthylamine (R = OMe, Me, H, CF3). The π-π interactions between the capping aryl groups and the pyridyl ring are clearly observed, which are a crucial driving force for highly active ethylene polymerization. The existence of syn and anti diastereomers of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes are also confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Ethylene polymerization using the bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt catalyst Co-OMe affords ultra-broad MWD PE (MWD >100) with M w from hundreds to ten million with a quartet-modal distribution. Mechanistic studies identified two different chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to ethylene monomer for low-molecular-weight PE and chain transfer to aluminum for high-molecular-weight PE in cobalt-catalyzed ethylene polymerization. The formation of ultra-broad MWD PE is a cooperative result of syn and anti diastereomers of cobalt catalysts and two chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to monomer and chain transfer to aluminum. This study opens a new avenue for tailoring molecular weight (MW) and molecular weight distribution (MWD) by combining complex diastereomers with different chain transfer modes in single-site metal catalyzed ethylene polymerization. coredata.dc:description: As the largest amount of worldwide produced polymeric materials, the broad applicability requires polyethylene (PE) to possess good processability and mechanical properties through tailored molecular weight (MW) and molecular weight distribution (MWD). Direct synthesis of broad MWD PE with ultra-high molecular weight component is highly desirable and challenging. In this paper, a series of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes with substituted 8-(p-R-phenyl)naphthylamine (R = OMe, Me, H, CF3) were designed and synthesized for ethylene polymerization. The intramolecular π-π interactions between the capping aryl groups and the pyridyl ring are clearly observed in bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes, which are a crucial driving force for highly active ethylene polymerization. The existence of syn and anti diastereomers of bis(imino)pyridyl cobalt complexes is also proved by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The ultra-broad MWD PE (MWD >100) with M w from hundreds to ten million is produced, which is a cooperative result of syn and anti diastereomers of cobalt catalysts and two chain transfer pathways involving β-H transfer to the monomer and chain transfer to aluminum.
